noun.description: Painful involuntary contraction of a muscle or muscles, typically caused by fatigue or strain.
examples: he suffered severe cramps in his foot

noun.description: A tool, typically shaped like a capital G, for clamping two objects together for gluing or other work.

verb.description: Restrict or inhibit the development of.
examples: tighter rules will cramp economic growth

verb.description: Fasten with a cramp or cramps.
examples: cramp the gates to the posts

verb.description: Suffer from sudden and painful contractions of a muscle or muscles.

phrases: At least we know this parenthood gig isn't going to cramp our style.
A coalition government and a secular constitution have cramped their style.
I got sick during the world champs which cramped my style, but I didn't shame myself.
The truth has not cramped their style in the past and is unlikely to do so during the current confirmation hearings.
I prefer action stories; dull conferences can cramp my style.
origin: Late Middle English: from Middle Low German and Middle Dutch krampe; sense 1 of the noun is via Old French crampe.
